journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Numerical simulation of a relaxation test designed to fit a quasi-linear viscoelastic model for temporomandibular joint discs

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Seville, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Maria S Commisso, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Seville, Camino de los descubrimientos s/n, E41092, Spain. Email: mcommisso1@us.es

abstract.p: The main objectives of this work are: (a) to introduce an algorithm for adjusting the quasi-linear viscoelastic model to fit a material using a stress relaxation test and (b) to validate a protocol for performing such tests in temporomandibular joint discs. This algorithm is intended for fitting the Prony series coefficients and the hyperelastic constants of the quasi-linear viscoelastic model by considering that the relaxation test is performed with an initial ramp loading at a certain rate. This algorithm was validated before being applied to achieve the second objective. Generally, the complete three-dimensional formulation of the quasi-linear viscoelastic model is very complex. Therefore, it is necessary to design an experimental test to ensure a simple stress state, such as uniaxial compression to facilitate obtaining the viscoelastic properties. This work provides some recommendations about the experimental setup, which are important to follow, as an inadequate setup could produce a stress state far from uniaxial, thus, distorting the material constants determined from the experiment. The test considered is a stress relaxation test using unconfined compression performed in cylindrical specimens extracted from temporomandibular joint discs. To validate the experimental protocol, the test was numerically simulated using finite-element modelling. The disc was arbitrarily assigned a set of quasi-linear viscoelastic constants (c1) in the finite-element model. Another set of constants (c2) was obtained by fitting the results of the simulated test with the proposed algorithm. The deviation of constants c2 from constants c1 measures how far the stresses are from the uniaxial state. The effects of the following features of the experimental setup on this deviation have been analysed: (a) the friction coefficient between the compression plates and the specimen (which should be as low as possible); (b) the portion of the specimen glued to the compression plates (smaller areas glued are better); and (c) the variation in the thickness of the specimen. The specimen’s faces should be parallel to ensure a uniaxial stress state. However, this is not possible in real specimens, and a criterion must be defined to accept the specimen in terms of the specimen’s thickness variation and the deviation of the fitted constants arising from such a variation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The temporomandibular joint (TMJ), together with several jaw muscles, perform physiological functions such as chewing, swallowing, speech and expression.1 It is estimated that 20–25% of the population suffers from disorders of this joint with most of these disorders being related to a malfunction of the fibrous component.2 To understand the TMJ’s complex biomechanics, it is important to correctly characterize the articular disc. The disc comprises mainly macromolecules (15–35%) and fluid, which is principally water.3 The content of proteoglycans in the TMJ disc is only 1–5% of its dry weight, which is low compared to hyaline cartilage. Proteoglycans are hydrophilic and thus produce an impedance to the flow of the interstitial fluid throughout the extracellular matrix. The lower concentration of these macromolecules makes a viscoelastic model more suitable to simulate the behaviour of the articular disc as opposed to a poroelastic or biphasic model, which rely upon modelling the drag force between the fluid and the solid matrix.4

In recent years, numerous studies characterizing the mechanical behaviour of the TMJ disc have been published. The characterization studies available have varied greatly due to the differences among the animal models and the test modalities.5–9 Additionally, data related to the TMJ disc’s viscoelastic nature and its ability to undergo finite deformations during normal function are scarce. Many authors have used linear viscoelasticity to relate the stress and strain using the Voigt, Maxwell and Kelvin models.3,4,10 However, for large displacements and/or strains, these models might not be valid, and the non-linear stress–strain characteristics of these tissues must be considered.11

Fung’s quasi-linear viscoelastic (QLV) model has been used to describe the behaviour of a large number of soft tissues.11–14 It has the advantage that the required material functions can be obtained from relatively simple experiments. In this work, the QLV model is proposed to characterize the articular disc of the TMJ of pigs. As has been suggested by Bermejo et al.15 and recently by Kalpakci et al.,16 the pig is the experimental animal that most closely resembles human beings, especially for studies of the temporomandibular articular complex.

The goal of this paper is to validate a simple testing procedure to characterize the QLV behaviour of the articular disc in the TMJ. As a second objective, an algorithm proposed to obtain the material constants from stress relaxation tests is validated. The simplest loading case that can be used to characterize a material is a uniaxial tension or compression test; however, the experimental setup can generate a more complex stress state if, specially, the thickness of the specimen is small, which makes it more difficult to extract the material properties. Therefore, to accomplish the first objective, it is important to control certain testing conditions to ensure that the stress state is as close to uniaxial as possible. Some works4,17 have recently studied the response of this tissue in unconfined compression tests, but the degree to which the testing conditions might affect the results was not analysed. In the proposed setup, to perform the stress relaxation tests, a cylindrical specimen was glued to a plate and compressed following a loading ramp. Many factors may make the stress state not uniaxial. Among these factors, the following have been selected to be studied: (a) the size of the area of the disc glued to the compression plate; (b) the friction coefficient between the non-glued parts and the compression plate; and (c) the variation in thickness across the specimen. This paper focuses only on these geometrical and mechanical aspects. Other factors, like the testing temperature, the ionic strength of the solution, the freeze/thaw cycles of the sample, to name a few, may have even a more marked influence on the results; however, that influence is more conveniently analysed with real experiments, testing the specimens under different conditions, than with a finite-element (FE) model.

Several studies have estimated the viscoelastic response of the articular disc of the TMJ;4,17 however, the relaxation occurring during ramp loading has not been considered there. The present algorithm has been developed to incorporate the relaxation manifested during loading, in a simple manner.

Another question that needs to be addressed is the anisotropy of the tissue, which originates from the collagen fibre network. However, these fibres primarily affect the stiffness of the disc in tension, while, in compression, the effect of reinforcement is almost negligible.3,18 This paper is focused on the compressive behaviour of the disc, which is predominant in a great part of the disc in jaw closing movements. Therefore, an isotropic model of the tissue was considered here.

Prony series are used in this paper to characterize the viscoelastic part of the QLV model, and two independent hyperelastic models, polynomial and exponential, are implemented for the elastic response. Prony series have been widely used in the literature to adjust the viscoelastic behaviour of the articular disc17 and other soft tissues.19,20 Yet, the algorithm could be easily applied to other relaxation functions if Prony series are not suitable. The validation of the curve-fitting algorithm has been performed using an FE simulation of the uniaxial compression test (using a single element). Then, other FE simulations of the relaxation test were performed to study the influence of the testing conditions on the QLV constants found with the proposed fitting algorithm. These simulations were performed on a model of the specimen whose geometry was approximated to that of certain samples. The samples were harvested from the articular disc of pigs just to know that geometry.

sec.title: QLV model
sec.p: In Fung’s approach, the history of the stress response, called the relaxation function, σ(λ,t), is factorized using a normalized function of time, called the reduced relaxation function, G¯(t), and a function of the stretch, λ, called the elastic response, T(e). If a tensile stretch (or shortening) is applied on a cylindrical specimen as a step function, the stress developed is given by the model as
where T(e) represents the Cauchy stress that would be produced if no relaxation had taken place.

It is assumed that the stress response to changes in stretch can be evaluated using the Boltzmann superposition principle, and if the specimen is stress and strain free at time t=0, the stress can be expressed as
If G¯(t) is assumed to be continuously differentiable, the expression can also be written as
The relaxation function used is a two-term Prony series as

where g1, g2 and g∞ are the short-term, mid-term and long-term relaxation coefficients, respectively. And τ1 and τ2 are the short-term and mid-term relaxation times. To define the elastic response, Te(λ), an incompressible hyperelastic model was defined to account for the non-linear stress–strain characteristics. First, a three-parameter polynomial model was used as in Li et al.,21 with the following strain energy function
where I1 and I2 are the first and second invariants of the right Cauchy–Green tensor and C10, C01 and C11 are the material constants.

Then, a second hyperelastic model was analysed to verify if the choice made to define Te(λ) has any influence on the sensitivity of the fitting algorithm. The following exponential strain energy function was chosen

where A and B are the material constants. This function was proposed by Humphrey and Yin22 for passive cardiac tissue and has been shown to fit well some preliminary tests performed on articular disc of pigs.

Because of the lack of data for the TMJ disc, the QLV model constants mentioned above were from the interpubic disc and were taken from Li et al.21 as C10=0.1MPa, C01=0.45MPa, C11=0.6MPa, g1=0.015, g2=0.25, τ1=1.45s and τ2=32.25s, while for the second hyperelastic model, the constants used were fitted from preliminary experimental tests carried out for this study, yielding: A=0.1MPa and B=3.28; the Prony series parameters were assumed equal in both models.

sec.title: FE model
sec.p: Two FE models have been analysed with the commercial code ABAQUS® v6.10 as follows: (a) a single element under uniaxial compression to validate the algorithm and (b) a model of a real specimen to study the influence of setup conditions.

First, a single eight-node hexahedral hybrid element (C3D8H) was subjected to a relaxation test under uniaxial compression. This case is referred to as the uniaxial compression model (UCM). The simulation solution of a single element with ideal boundary conditions during uniaxial compression is only affected by the numerical approximation, which is, in particular, the time integration of the viscoelastic effect. Therefore, this uniaxial compression case allows for the validation of the algorithm and the investigation of how this numerical approximation influences the constants obtained. More precisely, if the material is assumed to have a set of QLV constants c1, the algorithm is shown to be valid if the algorithm fits, using this simulation, a set of constants c2 close enough to c1 for any set c1.

Second, a model of the specimen has been analysed to simulate the real experiment under different configurations. To consider the variability in the actual specimen thicknesses, a set of real specimens was measured. A total of 22 articular discs were dissected from male large white pigs, aged from 8 months to 1 year. From the central region of those discs, cylindrical specimens with an approximately circular cross-sectional area were extracted using a hollow punch. The area of each specimen was measured using image analysis with the public domain software ImageJ, which resulted in an average diameter of 5.47±0.20 mm (mean ± standard deviation). The specimen thickness was measured, using optic microscopy (Nikon Optiphot XPF-M, 10x), at nine points equally spaced over the periphery of each sample, and an average of 2.55±0.34 mm (mean ± standard deviation) was obtained.

A cylindrical sample of 2.5 mm in thickness and with a circular cross-sectional area of diameter 5.5 mm was used for these simulations. After performing a mesh convergence study, the specimen was meshed with 12,056 elements (C3D8H). The modelled disc was compressed with two plates that were modelled as rigid solids. Contact pairs were used to simulate the unilateral contact with friction between the specimen and the plates. The deformation applied to the specimens (as well as the UCM model) was λ0=0.7 at a loading rate v=20 mm/min, and a relaxation time of 15 minutes was allowed in the FE simulations. Different loading rates and relaxation times have been used in the literature to obtain the compressive mechanical properties of the articular disc.4,5 In Lamela et al.,17 no further relaxation occurred after 100 s, so the relaxation time of 900 s allowed here seems to be enough to observe a complete relaxation. The deformation rate applied was chosen between 3 mm/min, used by Allen and Athanasiou,4 and 60 mm/min, used by del Pozo et al.5

As stated above, certain conditions in the experimental setup may have a large influence on the complexity of the stress state, and may cause the stress state to be different from the uniaxial state. Among those conditions, the following ones have been studied.

sec.title: Glued area
sec.p: To hold the specimen to the testing machine, it is necessary to glue one of the surfaces to the plate (the inferior surface was chosen in this case). Several setups were studied using the FE simulations: A1, the complete inferior surface was fixed (constraining the displacements of the C3D8H elements) to the inferior plate; A2, only a central area with diameter 1.5 mm was fixed; and A3, only one point, or one node in the FE model (the centre of the inferior surface), was fixed. However, because this last case cannot be performed in the real experiment, it was simulated as a reference because it produces the stress state closest to uniaxial. For all these cases, a friction coefficient of μ=0.01 and a constant thickness were used.

sec.title: Friction coefficient
sec.p: The contact between the superior surface and the plate and the non-adhered inferior areas, were simulated as a finite sliding contact with different friction coefficients: F1, μ=0.5; F2, μ=0.1; and F3, μ=0.01. A central glued area with a diameter of 1.5 mm and with a constant thickness was considered for each case. It should be noted that cases A2 and F3 are the same.

sec.title: Variation in thickness
sec.p: The specimens obtained from the discs had a great variation in the thickness. The difference between the maximum and minimum thickness measured, Δl, was used to characterize the variation. The discs are modelled assuming they have planar surfaces (see Figure 1). The following cases were tested: E1, where Δl=0.5 mm; E2, Δl=1 mm; and E3, Δl=1.1 mm. An average thickness of 2.5 mm, a central glued area with a diameter of 1.5 mm and μ=0.01 was used for the three cases.

caption.p: Finite-element model used to analyse the effect of the thickness variation.

sec.p: The initial contact in the real experiments could be achieved using an optic device, and then, the superior plate could be adjusted to the mean thickness; therefore, producing a pre-compression of the specimen, which would it make necessary to wait a period of time for the stresses to relax. Therefore, in the FE simulations, the position of the superior plate was initially placed at the average thickness (2.5 mm) in all cases. Then, the first step of the simulation solved this contact interference problem letting the specimen relax completely thereafter.

sec.title: Algorithm
sec.p: In a strict sense, the measurement of T(e)[λ(t)] requires the application of the load as a step function, which is practically impossible. If the loading rate is high enough to reasonably approximate a step function, the transient stress waves can be induced in the specimen and the recordings will be confused by those elastic waves. Therefore, a ramp loading λ=λ(t), similar to the one shown in Figure 2, with a moderate loading rate must be applied. The deformation reached at the end on the ramp (t0) is given by λ0. Generally, in relaxation tests, a step function is assumed to be the loading type and equation (1) is used to describe the stress response; however, if the real ramp loading is considered, equations (2) or (3) must be used instead.
The algorithm is divided into three steps.

Step 1. For this step only, it is assumed that the load is applied as a step (λ=λ0H(t), where H(t) is the Heaviside step function). If so, the stress response for (t>t0) is the stress relaxation function, which can be described by a two-term Prony series. Time needs to be redefined as (tr=t−t0). The stress response for tr>0 is given by equations (1) and (4) as

and is fitted to the experimental response (or the FE simulated response in this case) in the least mean squares sense. This results in the first estimation of the parameters σ∞, A1, A2, τ1 and τ2. The parameters σ∞, A1 and A2 are related to the relaxation coefficients
Step 2. The ramp phase (0<t<t0) is analysed in this step. The shortening is written as

where e(t) is the deformation, v is the loading rate (20 mm/min, as stated previously) and l is the specimen thickness. For an incompressible material under uniaxial tension or compression in direction 1, the principal stretches are λ1=λ, λ2=λ3=λ−1/2. In the polynomial hyperelastic model with three parameters, T(e) is then expressed, for uniaxial stress, as
For an incompressible and hyperelastic material with an exponential form of the strain energy function, in uniaxial stress, T(e) is

The real experiment has an initial ramp during a finite time and the relaxation that occurs during this time must be considered. This is performed by substituting equations (10) or (11) into equation (3). The material constants of the hyperelastic part of the model (C10, C01 and C11 or A and B) can be obtained by fitting equation (3) to the stress response over the period 0<t<t0. The material constants have to remain positive for consistency. An interior point penalty method was implemented to constrain the least square optimization (see Vanderplaats23 for further details). In this step, the Prony series parameters are constant and equal to the parameters fitted in step 1.
Step 3. The relaxation stress record is used to fit the Prony series parameters using equation (2), whose integration limits can be reduced to

because dλdτ=vl for t≤t0 and dλdτ=0 for t>t0. In this step, C10, C01 and C11; or A and B are kept constant and equal to those fitted in step 2. Equation (12) is applied to the relaxation period (t>t0) and fitted to the stress response over that period to obtain a second estimation of the Prony constants. The interior point penalty method is implemented at this step also to solve the optimization problem, forcing the relaxation coefficients to remain positive.
The second and third steps are repeated until convergence is achieved. To finish the iterative procedure, any of the following two convergence criteria must be achieved

where σ¯j(ti) is the stress obtained with the algorithm for iteration j at time ti and σ(ti) is the corresponding Cauchy stress obtained from the FE simulations of the test, and assuming that the material behaviour follows the QLV model, μσ is the mean of the temporal record σ(ti). The CV is the coefficient of variation of the root-mean-squared error and is a measure of the difference between the stresses obtained with the FE simulations and those obtained from the fitting procedure. The CV must be lower than 5·10−3 for convergence. The second condition (equation (14)) stops the iterative procedure when the change between consecutive iterations is small enough. This second tolerance is established at 5·10−8. These tolerances were defined after a convergence analysis to reach a compromise between computational cost and acceptable error. The maximum number of iterations (steps 2 and 3 are considered a single iteration) to achieve any of the allowed tolerance was four, and generally, the second condition was achieved first.
Because the FE stresses are not perfectly uniaxial, an average Cauchy stress has been defined to represent the stress state in the FE model

where RF is the reaction force and u is the displacement (negative in compression) seen in the FE simulations of the superior platen. A0 is the initial area of the specimen and l is the average thickness (2.5 mm).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The influence of the testing conditions on the results are shown for the simulations using the polynomial hyperelastic model. The most critical setup feature turned out to be the variation in thickness. Then, the effect of this variation is also analysed with the model using the exponential strain energy function because the influence of the other setup features are similar in both cases.

sec.title: Polynomial model
sec.p: Figure 3 shows, with the black solid line, the stress record obtained in the UCM. This case is used as a reference and is compared in this figure with the stresses found when the stress relaxation test is simulated in the disc using different test conditions. It can be seen that the shape of the relaxation curve is essentially the same for every case and the stresses during the relaxation are determined by the peak stress, which is strongly affected by the experimental conditions.

caption.p: Average Cauchy stress (see equation 15) during the relaxation test simulated in the UCM and the following cases: (a) different areas glued, μ=0.01, Δl=0, (b) various friction coefficients, central area glued (Φ=1.5 mm), Δl=0 and (c) different variations in the thickness, central area glued, μ=0.01. The polynomial model was used to describe the material behaviour.

sec.p: In Figure 3(a), the effect of the glued area is compared, and it can be seen that a smaller glued area results in the stress being closer to the reference case. The closest case to the uniaxial stress state is when only one point is fixed (corresponding to Φ=0). Moreover, the glued areas with diameter 0.5 mm, 1 mm or 1.5 mm yield almost the same stress curve. A wider glued area is easier to practically obtain in the laboratory. Thus, a diameter of 1.5 mm was selected and called case A2.
In the stress distribution shown in Figure 4, cases A1 and A2 are observed to present a more uniform distribution compared to the case with the inferior contact surface completely adhered, case A3.

caption.p: Stress distribution in the compression direction for the various cases analysed for the polynomial model. For simplicity, to analyse the glued area, only the remarkable cases are presented.

sec.p: Regarding the effect of friction, an improvement in the results is clear if the lowest possible coefficient is used: the stress distribution in the specimen is more uniform (see Figure 4), and consequently, the stress record is closer to the UCM (see Figure 3(b)). In addition, the peak stresses of cases F2 and F3 are closer to the UCM than that of case F1.

The variation in the thickness generates a non-uniform stress state in the specimen (see Figure 4) and makes the stress record diverge from the uniaxial case. The influence of this variation is high, as seen in Figure 3(c). The case Δl=0 considers the disc as perfectly cylindrical; therefore, it includes only the effect of friction and the glued area, and by comparing this curve with those below, an increasing influence of Δl is observed. The first step in all the FE simulations was to establish the contact, as stated above, and for that reason, all the curves begin at time t=1 s.

To analyse the results, the constants assigned to the material (previously referred to as c1 and listed in the second column in Table 1) can be compared with those fitted for each stress record (c2 and corresponding to the next column in each case). The constants fitted from the UCM case are almost identical to those assigned to the material. Other sets of constants have been compared with the same result, which confirms the validity of the proposed algorithm.

caption.p: Constants c1 assigned to the model (second column) and c2 (the rest of the columns) obtained by applying the algorithm to the stress record of the different FE simulations with the polynomial model. aLi et al.21

sec.p: If the other columns are compared, the results show that the fitted Prony series parameters are similar for most cases but the hyperelastic constants vary greatly with the test condition.

sec.title: Exponential model
sec.p: Because the hyperelastic constants were strongly affected by the thickness variation through the specimen, it is interesting to study that influence for a different hyperelastic model. Therefore, as performed previously, the UCM is used as the reference case and the following cases for analysis: A2, where Δl=0; E1, where Δl=0.5 mm; and E2, where Δl=1 mm. Figure 5 represents the stress record for the cases mentioned.

caption.p: Average Cauchy stress (see equation (15)) during the relaxation test simulated in the UCM and the following cases: A2, only a central area of 1.5 mm in the diameter was adhered, Δl=0 and μ=0.01; E1, Δl=0.5 mm, Φ=1.5 mm and μ=0.01; and E2, Δl=1 mm, Φ=1.5 mm and μ=0.01. The exponential model was used to describe the material behaviour.

sec.p: As expected, the relaxation curves are essentially the same, but differ in the peak stress, which shifts the stress record during relaxation. An increase in Δl produces an increase in the peak stress.

To study the influence of the boundary conditions for a different hyperelastic model, the algorithm was applied to fit the constants that were fitted from each stress record (see Table 2). The results can be compared with those assigned to the material in the FE model (second column).

caption.p: Constants c1 assigned to the model (second column) and c2 (the rest of the columns) obtained by applying the algorithm to the stress record of the different FE simulations using an exponential form for the strain energy function. aLi et al.21bObtained from preliminary tests.

sec.p: In the case of the UCM, the constants obtained are almost the same assigned to the material in the simulations, which confirms the validity of the proposed algorithm for a different strain energy function. The results show that the fitted Prony series parameters are similar in all cases. The constant A, from the hyperelastic formulation, is almost identical for the four cases analysed, while there is a difference in the fitted B obtained, specifically when Δl is increased in the specimen, though this difference is smaller than in the differences in the constants fitted in the polynomial model.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Different friction coefficients have been used to analyse its influence in the results. Two values that define the range of normal friction coefficients have been selected and also a very high value (0.5) in order to visualize the effect of a specially high friction coefficient. Comparing the cases F1, F2 and F3, it is clear that the friction coefficient has a more important effect in the hyperelastic constants than in the Prony series parameters. Only the short-term relaxation time seems to be affected by the increase in the friction. The results show that a high value of μ yields fitted constants that are far from the assigned ones and a peak stress far from the UCM. Then, such high values are not desirable. On the contrary, low values of μ, like cases F2 (0.1) and F3 (0.01) produced peak stresses closer to the UCM and fitted constants similar to the assigned ones. A friction coefficient as low as 0.01 cannot be easily achieved in real experiments, but the results show that 0.1 could still be acceptable, while practically feasible.

Comparing the cases A1, A2 and A3, the viscoelastic and hyperelastic constants are different to the actual constants if the complete area is adhered, but the constants are quite similar in the other two cases. Furthermore, special care should be taken in the gluing technique to limit the glued areas without contaminating the non-glued areas, which could affect the friction coefficient there.

Finally, analysing the constants for different thickness ranges shows that both the polynomial and the Prony series parameters are influenced by this variation, which is seen by obtaining values farther from the actual values as Δl is increased. It can be noted in Figure 3(c) that the peak stress obtained for E2 is relatively far from that of UCM and the difference is growing for E3, despite the small increase in Δl. Conversely, the peak stress for E1 is quite similar to the reference UCM. However, the sets of constants fitted for E1, E2 and E3 differ from the actual constants, even for E1, which has quasi-parallel faces (Δl=0.5) and a similar peak stress. The main differences are present in the hyperelastic constants, C10, C01 and C11, and in the short-term magnitude, g1, which are these parameters that have a greater influence on the peak stresses. Therefore, the peak stress in case E1 is only 6.7% greater than that of UCM; however, C10 is 3.7 times greater, C01 is 1.7 times less, C11 is 1.2 times greater and g1 is 2.2 times greater. This would indicate a large sensitivity of the model constants to the variation in the thickness or the possibility that different sets of constants would yield the same overall behaviour, as stated by Lanczos24 for the Prony series expansion.

Conversely, if the exponential form of the strain energy function is used to describe the elastic response, the differences in the peak stresses are even higher than the stresses obtained using the polynomial hyperelastic model. For the case of E2, the increase is 47.6% in peak stress and 15.9% for the case of E1. The fitting of constant A is nearly the same in all the analysed cases, and the variation of parameter B is not as important as the variation in the peak stress in the case of E2, which is almost 11%, and 5.5% in the case of E1. These results show a lower sensitivity of the fitted constants using the exponential model and a greater sensitivity to the model constants. The Prony series parameters are also closer to the assigned parameters when the exponential form is used. The fitted g1 is 40% lower than the actual g1 in the case of E2 and when the polynomial function is used, while this parameter is only 13.3% lower when the exponential function is used.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The QLV theory has been used to analyse a relaxation test in the articular disc of the TMJ of pigs. Using a simple model of uniaxial compression, it was possible to validate the developed algorithm and, with this algorithm, to analyse the different boundary conditions that simulate the actual experimental setup. The objective was to propose a testing procedure to characterize the QLV behaviour of the articular disc. For this goal, it is important to control certain parameters of the experiment to ensure that the stress state is as close to uniaxial as possible.
In addition, the algorithm developed in this work incorporates the relaxation manifested during loading, in a simple form.

Because the constants fitted from the uniaxial compression test of a single element are almost identical to those assigned to the material, the proposed algorithm appears to be valid. Then, the difference between the assigned constants and those fitted for a certain experimental configuration can be useful as a measure of how close a configuration is to uniaxial stress state. The differences are more noticeable in the hyperelastic constants than in the Prony series parameters, for which only the short-term parameters (g1 and τ1) show any discrepancies. In fact, both differences (the short-term Prony parameters and the hyperelastic constants) arise from the peak of the stress history, which is highly influenced by the actual boundary conditions.

The conclusions drawn from the uniformity of the stresses (Figure 4) are confirmed with the constants fitted with the algorithm (Table 1). The conclusions drawn are that it is sufficient to glue only a small area of the specimen to the compression plate and that the friction coefficients and the variation in thickness must be maintained as low as possible. This variation is likely to be the most influential factor and the most difficult to overcome because the variation in the specimen thickness may be high, which was shown by the measurements made in this work. The results have shown a strong sensitivity of the model constants to a non-uniform thickness. To check whether other models of the hyperelastic part exhibit a lower sensitivity, an exponential function of the strain energy was also used. The previously discussed results showed that the fitted constants are closer to the assigned constants for the exponential function, even though the peak stress differs much more compared with the UCM. The fitted short-term magnitude of the Prony series is more accurate than the parameters obtained using the polynomial model.

To establish a criteria for rejection of the specimens, the hyperelastic form that better describes the material behaviour has to be considered first. In the polynomial description, the stress record obtained for E1 is quite similar to UCM, despite the different constants arising from E1. Therefore, the specimens with this variation in thickness are considered valid, while specimens with Δl>0.5 mm must be rejected. This is quite a restrictive condition. For instance, 80% of the specimens that were extracted in this study for thickness measurement should be rejected. Alternately, if the exponential function properly fits the material response, only specimens with Δl>1 mm would need to be rejected because the variation in thickness produces a 10% error in one of the fitted constants. The peak stresses are overestimated in a more distinct way, despite the small differences in the constants. Therefore, the rejection of specimens with Δl>0.5 mm is also recommended in the materials modelled with the exponential strain energy function.

Finally, it is important to remark that in the present study, it was assumed that a QLV model can describe the mechanical behaviour of the articular disc of the TMJ. However, this assumption still needs to be checked out. For this reason, experimental tests following the recommendations of this work should be performed to confirm the applicability of the QLV model.
